standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac34 + \dfrac24 = \dfrac6{4}$ true?  [[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.  [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac34} + \blueD{\dfrac24}$ covers *less* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac64}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth. In the first fraction bar, the first 3 parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled three-fourths. In the second fraction bar, the first 2 parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-fourths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-fourths plus two-fourths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth. In the first fraction bar, all 4 parts are shaded purple. In the second fraction bar, the first 2 parts are shaded purple. A curved bracket above all shaded parts together is labeled six-fourths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded green with a curved bracked above them labeled three-fourths. The last part in the first fraction bar is shaded blue. The second fraction bar has one part equal to those of the first bar and is shaded blue. The rest of the second bar is undivided. A curved bracket above the last part of the first bar and the blue part of second bar is labeled two-fourths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-fourths plus two-fourths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts all shaded purple. The second fraction bar has 2 parts equal to those of the first bar which are shaded purple. The rest of the second bar is undivided. A curved bracket above all the shaded parts together is labeled six-fourths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac34 + \dfrac14 = \dfrac48$ true?  [[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.  [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac34} + \blueD{\dfrac14}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac48}$, so the equation was *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth. In the first fraction bar, the first 3 parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled three-fourths. In the second fraction bar, the first part is shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled one-fourth. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-fourths plus one-fourth.
A fraction bar divided into eight equal part, each part labeled one-eighth. Four parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above labeled four-eighths.

A fraction bar divided into four equal parts. The first 3 parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket labeled three-fourths. The last part is shaded blue with a curved bracket labeled one-fourth. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-fourths plus one-fourth.
A fraction bar divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is further divided into four equal parts that are shaded purple with a curved bracket labeled four-eighths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac34 + \dfrac24 = \dfrac54$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.  [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac34} + \blueD{\dfrac24}$ covers the *same* area as $\purpleD{\dfrac54}$, so the equation is true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth. In the first fraction bar, the first 3 parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled three-fourths. In the second fraction bar, the first 2 parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-fourths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-fourths plus two-fourths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth. In the first fraction bar, all 4 parts are shaded purple. In the second fraction bar, the first part is shaded purple. A curved bracket above all shaded parts together is labeled five-fourths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded green with a curved bracked above them labeled three-fourths. The last part in the first fraction bar is shaded blue. The second fraction bar has one part equal to those of the first bar and is shaded blue. The rest of the second bar is undivided. A curved bracket above the last part of the first bar and the blue part of second bar is labeled two-fourths. Together the curved brackets are labeled three-fourths plus two-fourths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts all shaded purple. The second fraction bar has 1 part equal to those of the first bar and is shaded purple. The rest of the second bar is undivided. A curved bracket above all the shaded parts together is labeled five-fourths.

hints.content: The equation $\greenD{\dfrac34} + \blueD{\dfrac24} = \purpleD{\dfrac54}$ is true.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac23 + \dfrac23 = \dfrac4{6}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac23} + \blueD{\dfrac23}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac46}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-third. In the first fraction bar, the first two parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-thirds. In the second fraction bar, the first two parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-thirds. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-thirds plus two-thirds.
A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-sixth. Four parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-sixths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts. Two parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-thirds. The last part in the first fraction bar is shaded blue. The second fraction bar has one part equal to those of the first fraction bar and is shaded blue. The rest of the second fraction bar is undivided. A curved bracket above the last part of the first bar and the blue part of the second bar is labeled two-thirds. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-thirds plus two thirds.
A fraction bar divided into 5 parts. The first four parts are equal in size and are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-sixths. The last part is not shaded.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac12 + \dfrac32 = \dfrac44$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac12} + \blueD{\dfrac32}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac44}$, so the equation was *not* true.

images.alt: Three equal-sized fraction bars set in a row. Each fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-half. In the first fraction bar one part is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-half. All parts of the second fraction bar and one part of the third fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled three-halves. Together the curved bracket is labeled one-half plus three-halves.
A fraction bar divided into 4 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-fourth. All 4 parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-fourths.

Two fraction bars set side-by side. Each fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part of the first fraction bar is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-half.  The remaining part of the first fraction bar and all parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled three-halves. Together the curved brackets are labeled one-half plus three-halves.
A fraction bar divided into 4 equal parts. All parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-fourths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac48 + \dfrac28 = \dfrac68$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac48} + \blueD{\dfrac28}$ covers the *same* area as $\purpleD{\dfrac68}$, so the equation is true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 8 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-eight. Four parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-eighths. Two parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-eighths. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-eighths plus two-eighths.
A fraction bar divided into 8 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-eighth. Six parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled six-eighths.

A fraction bar divided into 7 parts. The first six parts are equal in size. Of these parts, four are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-eighths and two are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-eighths. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-eighths plus two-eighths. The last part of the fraction bar is not shaded.
A fraction bar divided into 7 parts. The first six parts are equal in size and are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled six-eighths. The last part of the fraction bar is not shaded.

hints.content: The equation $\greenD{\dfrac48} + \blueD{\dfrac28} = \purpleD{\dfrac68}$ is true.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac45+ \dfrac45 = \dfrac8{10}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.    [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac45} + \blueD{\dfrac45}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac8{10}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-fifth. Four parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-fifths. Four parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled four-fifths. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-fifths plus four-fifths.
A fraction bar divided into 10 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-tenth. Eight parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled eight-tenths.

Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. The first fraction bar is divided into 5 equal parts. Four parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-fifths. The last part in the first fraction bar is shaded blue. The second fraction part has three parts equal to those of the first fraction bar and is shaded blue. The rest of the second bar is undivided. A curved bracket above the last part of the first fraction bar and the blue part of the second fraction bar is labeled four-fifths. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-fifths plus four-fifths.
A fraction bar divided into 9 parts. The first 8 parts are equal in size and shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled eight-tenths. The last part is not shaded.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac16 + \dfrac36 = \dfrac4{12}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]    [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac16} + \blueD{\dfrac36}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac4{12}}$, so the equation was *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-sixth. One part of the first fraction bar is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-sixth. Three parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled three-sixths. Together the curved brackets are labeled one-sixth plus three-sixths.
A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-twelfth. Four parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-twelfths.

A fraction bar divided into 5 parts. The first four parts are equal in size. The first part is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-sixth. The next three parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled three-sixths. Together the curved brackets are labeled one-sixth plus three-sixths. The unshaded part is equal in size to two of the shaded parts.

A fraction bar divided into 5 parts. The first four parts are equal in size and shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-twelfths. The unshaded part is three times larger than the shaded parts.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac13 + \dfrac23 = \dfrac3{3}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac13} + \blueD{\dfrac23}$ covers the *same* area as $\purpleD{\dfrac33}$, so the equation is true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-third. One part of the first fraction bar is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-third. Two parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled two-thirds. Together the curved brackets are labeled one-third plus two-thirds.
A fraction bar divided into 3 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-third. All parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled three-thirds.

A fraction bar divided into 3 equal parts. The first part is shaded green with a curved bracket above it labeled one-third. The remaining two parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-thirds. Together the curved brackets are labeled one-third plus two-thirds.
A fraction bar divided into 3 equal parts. All parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled three-thirds.

hints.content: The equation $\greenD{\dfrac13} + \blueD{\dfrac23} = \purpleD{\dfrac33}$ is true.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac12+ \dfrac12 = \dfrac24$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.    [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac12} + \blueD{\dfrac12}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac24}$, so the equation is *not* true.

Together the curved brackets are labeled one-half plus one-half.

A fraction bar divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is further divided into 2 equal parts that are shaded purple with a curved bracket labeled two-fourths.

A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-sixth. Five parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled five-sixths.

Four parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled four-fifths. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-fifths plus four-fifths.

The second fraction bar has one part equal to those of the first fraction bar and is shaded purple. The rest of the second bar is undivided. question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac24+ \dfrac14 = \dfrac38$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac24} + \blueD{\dfrac14}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac38}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-fourth. Two parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-fourths. One part of the second fraction bar is shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled one-fourth. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-fourths plus one-fourth.
A fraction bar divided into 8 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-eighth. Three parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled three-eighths.

A fraction bar divided into four equal parts. The first two parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-fourths. The next part is shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled one-fourth. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-fourths plus one-fourth.

A fraction bar divided into 2 parts. The first part is further divided into 3 smaller parts, each equal to one-eighth of the length of the bar. The three smaller parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled three-eighths. The rest of the bar is undivided.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac26+ \dfrac26 = \dfrac56$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac26} + \blueD{\dfrac26}$ covers *less* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac5{6}}$, so the equation was *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-sixth. Two parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-sixths. Two parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-sixths. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-sixths plus two-sixths.
A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-sixth. Five parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled five-sixths.

A fraction bar divided into 2 parts. The first part is further divided into 4 smaller parts, each equal to one-fourth of the length of the bar. Two of the smaller parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled two-sixths and two parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled two-sixths. Together the curved brackets are labeled two-sixths plus two-sixths. The rest of the bar is undivided.
A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts. Five parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled five-sixths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac4{10} + \dfrac3{10} = \dfrac7{10}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.    [[☃ image 3]]   [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac4{10}} + \blueD{\dfrac3{10}}$ covers the *same* area as $\purpleD{\dfrac7{10}}$, so the equation is true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 10 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-tenth. Four parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-tenths. Three parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled three-tenths. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-tenths plus three-tenths.
A fraction bar divided into 10 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-tenth. Seven parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled seven-tenths.

A fraction bar divided into 2 parts. The first part is further divided into 7 smaller parts, each equal to one-tenth of the length of the bar. Four of the smaller parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-tenths and three parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled three-tenths. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-tenths plus three-tenths. The rest of the bar is undivided.

A fraction bar divided into 2 parts. The first part is further divided into 7 smaller parts, each equal to one-tenth of the length of the bar. The seven smaller parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled seven-tenths. The rest of the bar is undivided.

hints.content: The equation $\greenD{\dfrac4{10}} + \blueD{\dfrac3{10}} = \purpleD{\dfrac7{10}}$ is true.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac46+ \dfrac56 = \dfrac9{12}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.  [[☃ image 3]]    [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac46} + \blueD{\dfrac56}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac9{12}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.

##Is $\dfrac8{12} + \dfrac4{12} = \dfrac4{12}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.    [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac8{12}} + \blueD{\dfrac4{12}}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac4{12}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

Eight parts on the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled eight-twelfths. Four parts on the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled four-twelfths. Together the curved brackets are labeled eight-twelfths plus four-twelfths.
A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-twelfth. Four parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled four-twelfths.

A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts. Eight parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled eight-twelfths. Four parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled four-twelfths. Together the curved brackets are labeled eight-twelfths plus four-twelfths.

A fraction bar divided into 2 parts. The first part is further divided into 4 smaller parts, each part one-twelfth of the bar, shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled four-twelfths. The rest of the bar is undivided.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac46+ \dfrac16 = \dfrac5{12}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]    [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac46} + \blueD{\dfrac16}$ covers *more* area than $\purpleD{\dfrac5{12}}$, so the equation was *not* true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts, each part labeled one-sixth. Four parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-sixths. One part of the second fraction bar is shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled one-sixth. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-sixths plus one-sixth.
A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-twelfth. Five parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled five-twelfths.

A fraction bar divided into 6 equal parts. Four parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled four-sixths. One part is shaded blue with a curved bracket above it labeled one-sixth. Together the curved brackets are labeled four-sixths plus one-sixth.

A fraction bar divided into 2 parts. The first part is further divided into 5 smaller parts, each part one-twelfth of the bar, shaded purple with a curved bracket above it labeled five-twelfths. The rest of the bar is undivided.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac5{12} + \dfrac6{12} = \dfrac{11}{12}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]  Let's slide the shaded areas together to compare the values.   [[☃ image 3]]  [[☃ image 4]]  $\greenD{\dfrac5{12}} + \blueD{\dfrac6{12}}$ covers the *same* area as $\purpleD{\dfrac{11}{12}}$, so the equation is true.

images.alt: Two equal-sized fraction bars side-by-side. Each fraction bar is divided into 12 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-twelfth. Five parts of the first fraction bar are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled five-twelfths. Six parts of the second fraction bar are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled six-twelfths. Together the curved brackets are labeled five-twelfths plus six-twelfths.
A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts, and each part is labeled one-twelfth. Eleven parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled eleven-twelfths.

A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts. Five parts are shaded green with a curved bracket above them labeled five-twelfths. Six parts are shaded blue with a curved bracket above them labeled six-twelfths. Together the curved brackets are labeled five-twelfths plus six-twelfths.
A fraction bar divided into 12 equal parts. Eleven parts are shaded purple with a curved bracket above them labeled eleven-twelfths.

hints.content: The equation $\greenD{\dfrac5{12}} + \blueD{\dfrac6{12}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{11}{12}}$ is true.
